context: In <a0_0><b11_0>1994<b11_0/><a0_0/>, over a hundred intrusions were made by unidentified crackers into the <b13_0>Rome Laboratory<b13_0/>, <a3_0><b10_0>the US Air Force<b10_0/>'s main command and research facility<a3_0/>. <a1_0>Using <b7_0>trojan horses<b7_0/><a1_0/>, hackers were able to obtain unrestricted access to Rome's networking systems <b6_0>and <b9_0>remove traces of their activities<b9_0/><b6_0/>. The intruders were able to obtain <b5_0><b12_0>classified files<b12_0/>, such as air tasking order systems data<b5_0/> and furthermore able to penetrate connected networks of <a4_0>National Aeronautics and Space Administration<a4_0/>'s Goddard Space Flight Center, Wright-Patterson Air Force Base, some Defense contractors, and other private sector organizations, <a2_0>by <b14_0>posing as <b8_0>a trusted Rome center user<b14_0/><b8_0/><a2_0/>.
